trans-unit.source: Answers to frequently asked questions about the backup service, backup agent, backup and retention, recovery, security and other common questions about backup and disaster recovery.
trans-unit.target: Answers to frequently asked questions about the backup service, backup agent, backup and retention, recovery, security and other common questions about backup and disaster recovery.

trans-unit.source: This article is a list of commonly asked questions (and the respective answers) about the Azure Backup service.
trans-unit.target: This article is a list of commonly asked questions (and the respective answers) about the Azure Backup service.

trans-unit.source: Our community replies quickly, and if a question is asked often, we add it to this article.
trans-unit.target: Our community replies quickly, and if a question is asked often, we add it to this article.

trans-unit.source: The answers to questions typically provide reference or support information.
trans-unit.target: The answers to questions typically provide reference or support information.

trans-unit.source: You can ask questions about Azure Backup in the Disqus section of this article or a related article.
trans-unit.target: You can ask questions about Azure Backup in the Disqus section of this article or a related article.

trans-unit.source: You can also post questions about the Azure Backup service in the [discussion forum](https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/forums/azure/home?forum=windowsazureonlinebackup)
trans-unit.target: You can also post questions about the Azure Backup service in the [discussion forum](https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/forums/azure/home?forum=windowsazureonlinebackup)

trans-unit.source: What is the list of supported operating systems from which I can back up to Azure using Azure Backup?
trans-unit.target: What is the list of supported operating systems from which I can back up to Azure using Azure Backup?

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup supports the following list of operating systems
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup supports the following list of operating systems

trans-unit.source: Ultimate, Enterprise, Professional, Home Premium, Home Basic, Starter
trans-unit.target: Ultimate, Enterprise, Professional, Home Premium, Home Basic, Starter

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 R2 and latest SPs
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 R2 and latest SPs

trans-unit.source: Windows Storage Server 2012 R2 and latest SPs
trans-unit.target: Windows Storage Server 2012 R2 and latest SPs

trans-unit.source: Windows Storage Server 2012 and latest SPs
trans-unit.target: Windows Storage Server 2012 and latest SPs

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 R2 and latest SPs
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 R2 and latest SPs

trans-unit.source: Where can I download the latest Azure Backup agent?
trans-unit.target: Where can I download the latest Azure Backup agent?

trans-unit.source: You can download the latest agent for backing up Windows Server, System Center DPM, or Windows client, from [here](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent).
trans-unit.target: You can download the latest agent for backing up Windows Server, System Center DPM, or Windows client, from [here](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent).

trans-unit.source: If you want to back up a virtual machine, use the VM Agent (which automatically installs the proper extension).
trans-unit.target: If you want to back up a virtual machine, use the VM Agent (which automatically installs the proper extension).

trans-unit.source: The VM Agent is already present on virtual machines created from the Azure gallery.
trans-unit.target: The VM Agent is already present on virtual machines created from the Azure gallery.

trans-unit.source: Which version of SCDPM server is supported?
trans-unit.target: Which version of SCDPM server is supported?

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you install the [latest](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent) Azure Backup agent on the latest update rollup of SCDPM (UR6 as of July 2015)
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you install the [latest](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent) Azure Backup agent on the latest update rollup of SCDPM (UR6 as of July 2015)

trans-unit.source: **Q4. When configuring the Azure Backup agent, I am prompted to enter the **vault credentials**.
trans-unit.target: **Q4. When configuring the Azure Backup agent, I am prompted to enter the **vault credentials**.

trans-unit.source: Yes, the vault credentials expire after 48 hours.
trans-unit.target: Yes, the vault credentials expire after 48 hours.

trans-unit.source: If the file expires, log in to the Azure portal and download the vault credentials files from your Backup vault.
trans-unit.target: If the file expires, log in to the Azure portal and download the vault credentials files from your Backup vault.

trans-unit.source: Is there any limit on the number of backup vaults that can be created in each Azure subscription?
trans-unit.target: Is there any limit on the number of backup vaults that can be created in each Azure subscription?

trans-unit.source: As of July 2015, you can create 25 vaults per subscription.
trans-unit.target: As of July 2015, you can create 25 vaults per subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you need more vaults, then create a new subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you need more vaults, then create a new subscription.

trans-unit.source: Should I look at a vault as a billing entity?
trans-unit.target: Should I look at a vault as a billing entity?

trans-unit.source: Though it is possible to get a detailed bill for each vault, we highly recommend that you consider an Azure subscription as a billing entity.
trans-unit.target: Though it is possible to get a detailed bill for each vault, we highly recommend that you consider an Azure subscription as a billing entity.

trans-unit.source: It is consistent across all services and is easier to manage.
trans-unit.target: It is consistent across all services and is easier to manage.

trans-unit.source: Are there any limits on the number of servers/machines that can be registered against each vault?
trans-unit.target: Are there any limits on the number of servers/machines that can be registered against each vault?

trans-unit.source: Yes, you can register up to 50 machines per vault.
trans-unit.target: Yes, you can register up to 50 machines per vault.

trans-unit.source: For Azure IaaS virtual machines, limit is 200 VMs per vault.
trans-unit.target: For Azure IaaS virtual machines, limit is 200 VMs per vault.

trans-unit.source: If you need to register more machines, create a new vault.
trans-unit.target: If you need to register more machines, create a new vault.

trans-unit.source: Are there any limits on the amount of data that can be backed up from a Windows server/client or SCDPM server?
trans-unit.target: Are there any limits on the amount of data that can be backed up from a Windows server/client or SCDPM server?

trans-unit.source: How do I register my server to another datacenter?
trans-unit.target: How do I register my server to another datacenter?

trans-unit.source: Backup data is sent to the datacenter of the Backup Service to which it is registered.
trans-unit.target: Backup data is sent to the datacenter of the Backup Service to which it is registered.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to change the datacenter is to uninstall the agent and reinstall the agent and register to a new datacenter.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to change the datacenter is to uninstall the agent and reinstall the agent and register to a new datacenter.

trans-unit.source: What happens if I rename a Windows server that is backing up data to Azure?
trans-unit.target: What happens if I rename a Windows server that is backing up data to Azure?

trans-unit.source: When you rename a server, all currently configured backups are stopped.
trans-unit.target: When you rename a server, all currently configured backups are stopped.

trans-unit.source: You need to register the new name of the server with the Backup vault.
trans-unit.target: You need to register the new name of the server with the Backup vault.

trans-unit.source: When you create a new registration, the first backup operation is a full backup, and not an incremental backup.
trans-unit.target: When you create a new registration, the first backup operation is a full backup, and not an incremental backup.

trans-unit.source: If you need to recover data that was previously backed up to the vault with the old server name, you can recover that data using the [**Another server**](backup-azure-restore-windows-server.md#recover-to-an-alternate-machine) option in the **Recover Data** wizard.
trans-unit.target: If you need to recover data that was previously backed up to the vault with the old server name, you can recover that data using the [**Another server**](backup-azure-restore-windows-server.md#recover-to-an-alternate-machine) option in the **Recover Data** wizard.

trans-unit.source: What types of drives can I backup files and folders from?
trans-unit.target: What types of drives can I backup files and folders from?

trans-unit.source: The following set of drives/volumes can't be backup:
trans-unit.target: The following set of drives/volumes can't be backup:

trans-unit.source: Removable Media: The drive must report as a fixed to be used a backup item source.
trans-unit.target: Removable Media: The drive must report as a fixed to be used a backup item source.

trans-unit.source: Read-only Volumes: The volume must be writable for the volume shadow copy service (VSS) to function.
trans-unit.target: Read-only Volumes: The volume must be writable for the volume shadow copy service (VSS) to function.

trans-unit.source: Offline Volumes: The volume must be online for VSS to function.
trans-unit.target: Offline Volumes: The volume must be online for VSS to function.

trans-unit.source: Network share: The volume must be local to the server to be backed up using online backup.
trans-unit.target: Network share: The volume must be local to the server to be backed up using online backup.

trans-unit.source: Bitlocker protected volumes: The volume must be unlocked before the backup can occur.
trans-unit.target: Bitlocker protected volumes: The volume must be unlocked before the backup can occur.

trans-unit.source: File System Identification: NTFS is the only file system supported for this version of the online backup service.
trans-unit.target: File System Identification: NTFS is the only file system supported for this version of the online backup service.

trans-unit.source: What file and folder types can I back up from my server?
trans-unit.target: What file and folder types can I back up from my server?

trans-unit.source: What's the minimum size requirement for the cache folder?
trans-unit.target: What's the minimum size requirement for the cache folder?

trans-unit.source: The size of the cache folder determines the amount of data that you are backing up.
trans-unit.target: The size of the cache folder determines the amount of data that you are backing up.

trans-unit.source: Your cache folder should be 5% of the space required for data storage.
trans-unit.target: Your cache folder should be 5% of the space required for data storage.

trans-unit.source: If my organization has one backup vault, how can I isolate one server's data from another server when restoring data?
trans-unit.target: If my organization has one backup vault, how can I isolate one server's data from another server when restoring data?

trans-unit.source: All servers that are registered to the same vault can recover the data backed up by other servers *that use the same passphrase*.
trans-unit.target: All servers that are registered to the same vault can recover the data backed up by other servers *that use the same passphrase*.

trans-unit.source: If you have servers whose backup data you want to isolate from other servers in your organization, use a designated passphrase for those servers.
trans-unit.target: If you have servers whose backup data you want to isolate from other servers in your organization, use a designated passphrase for those servers.

trans-unit.source: For example, human resources servers could use one encryption passphrase, accounting servers another, and storage servers a third.
trans-unit.target: For example, human resources servers could use one encryption passphrase, accounting servers another, and storage servers a third.

trans-unit.source: Can I “migrate” my backup data between subscriptions?
trans-unit.target: Can I “migrate” my backup data between subscriptions?

trans-unit.source: Can I “migrate” my backup vault between subscriptions?
trans-unit.target: Can I “migrate” my backup vault between subscriptions?

trans-unit.source: The vault is created at a subscription level and cannot be reassigned to another subscription once it’s created.
trans-unit.target: The vault is created at a subscription level and cannot be reassigned to another subscription once it’s created.

trans-unit.source: Does the Azure Backup Agent work on a server that uses Windows Server 2012 deduplication?
trans-unit.target: Does the Azure Backup Agent work on a server that uses Windows Server 2012 deduplication?

trans-unit.source: The agent service converts the deduplicated data to normal data when it prepares the backup operation.
trans-unit.target: The agent service converts the deduplicated data to normal data when it prepares the backup operation.

trans-unit.source: It then optimizes the data for backup, encrypts the data, and then sends the encrypted data to the online backup service.
trans-unit.target: It then optimizes the data for backup, encrypts the data, and then sends the encrypted data to the online backup service.

trans-unit.source: If I cancel a backup job once it has started, is the transferred backup data deleted?
trans-unit.target: If I cancel a backup job once it has started, is the transferred backup data deleted?

trans-unit.source: The backup vault stores the backed-up data that had been transferred up to the point of the cancellation.
trans-unit.target: The backup vault stores the backed-up data that had been transferred up to the point of the cancellation.

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup uses a checkpoint mechanism to occasionally add checkpoints to the backup data during the backup.
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup uses a checkpoint mechanism to occasionally add checkpoints to the backup data during the backup.

trans-unit.source: Because there are checkpoints in the backup data, the next backup process can validate the integrity of the files.
trans-unit.target: Because there are checkpoints in the backup data, the next backup process can validate the integrity of the files.

trans-unit.source: The next backup triggered would be incremental over the data that had been backed up previously.
trans-unit.target: The next backup triggered would be incremental over the data that had been backed up previously.

trans-unit.source: An incremental backup provides better utilization of bandwidth, so that you do not need to transfer the same data repeatedly.
trans-unit.target: An incremental backup provides better utilization of bandwidth, so that you do not need to transfer the same data repeatedly.

trans-unit.source: Why am I seeing the warning "Azure Backups have not been configured for this server" even though I had scheduled regular backups previously?
trans-unit.target: Why am I seeing the warning "Azure Backups have not been configured for this server" even though I had scheduled regular backups previously?

trans-unit.source: A19: This warning occurs when the backup schedule settings stored on the local server are not the same as the settings stored in the backup vault.
trans-unit.target: A19: This warning occurs when the backup schedule settings stored on the local server are not the same as the settings stored in the backup vault.

trans-unit.source: When either the server or the settings have been recovered to a known good state, the backup schedules can lose synchronization.
trans-unit.target: When either the server or the settings have been recovered to a known good state, the backup schedules can lose synchronization.

trans-unit.source: If you receive this warning, [reconfigure the backup policy](backup-azure-backup-windows-server.md) and then **Run Back Up Now** to resynchronize the local server with Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you receive this warning, [reconfigure the backup policy](backup-azure-backup-windows-server.md) and then **Run Back Up Now** to resynchronize the local server with Azure.

trans-unit.source: What firewall rules should be configured for Azure Backup?
trans-unit.target: What firewall rules should be configured for Azure Backup?

trans-unit.source: For seamless protection of on-premises-to-Azure and workload-to-Azure data, it is recommended that you allow your firewall to communicate with the following URLs:
trans-unit.target: For seamless protection of on-premises-to-Azure and workload-to-Azure data, it is recommended that you allow your firewall to communicate with the following URLs:

trans-unit.source: Can I install the Azure Backup agent on an Azure VM already backed by the Azure Backup service using the VM extension?
trans-unit.target: Can I install the Azure Backup agent on an Azure VM already backed by the Azure Backup service using the VM extension?

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup provides VM-level backup for Azure VMs using the VM extension.
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup provides VM-level backup for Azure VMs using the VM extension.

trans-unit.source: You can install the Azure Backup agent on a Guest Windows OS to protect files and folders on that guest OS.
trans-unit.target: You can install the Azure Backup agent on a Guest Windows OS to protect files and folders on that guest OS.

trans-unit.source: Can I install the Azure Backup agent on an Azure VM to back up files and folders present on temporary storage provided by the Azure VM?
trans-unit.target: Can I install the Azure Backup agent on an Azure VM to back up files and folders present on temporary storage provided by the Azure VM?

trans-unit.source: You can install the Azure Backup agent on the Guest Windows OS and back up files and folders to temporary storage.
trans-unit.target: You can install the Azure Backup agent on the Guest Windows OS and back up files and folders to temporary storage.

trans-unit.source: However, please note that backups fail once temporary storage data is wiped out.
trans-unit.target: However, please note that backups fail once temporary storage data is wiped out.

trans-unit.source: Also, if the temporary storage data has been deleted, you can only restore to non-volatile storage.
trans-unit.target: Also, if the temporary storage data has been deleted, you can only restore to non-volatile storage.

trans-unit.source: What is the length of file path that can be specified as part of Azure Backup policy using Azure Backup agent?
trans-unit.target: What is the length of file path that can be specified as part of Azure Backup policy using Azure Backup agent?

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup agent relies on NTFS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup agent relies on NTFS.

trans-unit.source: The [file path length specification is limited by the Windows API](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/aa365247.aspx#fully_qualified_vs._relative_paths).
trans-unit.target: The [file path length specification is limited by the Windows API](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/aa365247.aspx#fully_qualified_vs._relative_paths).

trans-unit.source: If you have a file path greater than what is allowed by the Windows API, you can back up the parent folder, or the disk drive, of the desired files.
trans-unit.target: If you have a file path greater than what is allowed by the Windows API, you can back up the parent folder, or the disk drive, of the desired files.

trans-unit.source: What characters are allowed in file path of Azure Backup policy using Azure Backup agent?
trans-unit.target: What characters are allowed in file path of Azure Backup policy using Azure Backup agent?

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup agent relies on NTFS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup agent relies on NTFS.

trans-unit.source: It enables [NTFS supported characters](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/aa365247.aspx#naming_conventions) as part of file specification.
trans-unit.target: It enables [NTFS supported characters](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/aa365247.aspx#naming_conventions) as part of file specification.

trans-unit.source: Can I use Azure Backup Server to create a Bare Metal Recovery (BMR) backup for a physical server?
trans-unit.target: Can I use Azure Backup Server to create a Bare Metal Recovery (BMR) backup for a physical server?

trans-unit.source: Can I configure the Backup service to send mail if a backup job fails?
trans-unit.target: Can I configure the Backup service to send mail if a backup job fails?

trans-unit.source: Yes, the Backup service has several event-based alerts that can be used with a PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: Yes, the Backup service has several event-based alerts that can be used with a PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: Is there a limit on the size of each data source being backed up?
trans-unit.target: Is there a limit on the size of each data source being backed up?

trans-unit.source: As of August 2015, the maximum size data source for the supported operating systems is:
trans-unit.target: As of August 2015, the maximum size data source for the supported operating systems is:

trans-unit.source: The following table explains how each data source size is determined.
trans-unit.target: The following table explains how each data source size is determined.

trans-unit.source: The amount of data being backed up from single volume of a server or client machine
trans-unit.target: The amount of data being backed up from single volume of a server or client machine

trans-unit.source: Sum of data of all the VHDs of the virtual machine being backed up
trans-unit.target: Sum of data of all the VHDs of the virtual machine being backed up

trans-unit.source: Size of single SQL database size being backed up
trans-unit.target: Size of single SQL database size being backed up

trans-unit.source: Sum of the content and configuration databases within a SharePoint farm being backed up
trans-unit.target: Sum of the content and configuration databases within a SharePoint farm being backed up

trans-unit.source: Sum of all Exchange databases in an Exchange server being backed up
trans-unit.target: Sum of all Exchange databases in an Exchange server being backed up

trans-unit.source: Each individual copy of BMR or system state of the machine being backed up
trans-unit.target: Each individual copy of BMR or system state of the machine being backed up

trans-unit.source: Are there limits on the number of times a backup job can be scheduled per day?
trans-unit.target: Are there limits on the number of times a backup job can be scheduled per day?

trans-unit.source: Yes, you can run backup jobs on Windows Server or Windows client up to three times/day.
trans-unit.target: Yes, you can run backup jobs on Windows Server or Windows client up to three times/day.

trans-unit.source: You can run backup jobs on System Center DPM up to twice a day.
trans-unit.target: You can run backup jobs on System Center DPM up to twice a day.

trans-unit.source: You can run a backup job for IaaS VMs once a day.
trans-unit.target: You can run a backup job for IaaS VMs once a day.

trans-unit.source: Is there a difference between the scheduling policy for DPM and Windows Server (i.e. on Windows Server without DPM)?
trans-unit.target: Is there a difference between the scheduling policy for DPM and Windows Server (i.e. on Windows Server without DPM)?

trans-unit.source: Using DPM, you can specify daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly schedules.
trans-unit.target: Using DPM, you can specify daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly schedules.

trans-unit.source: Windows Server (without DPM) allows you to specify only daily and weekly schedules.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server (without DPM) allows you to specify only daily and weekly schedules.

trans-unit.source: Is there a difference between the retention policy for DPM and Windows Server/client (i.e. on Windows Server without DPM)?
trans-unit.target: Is there a difference between the retention policy for DPM and Windows Server/client (i.e. on Windows Server without DPM)?

trans-unit.source: No, both DPM and Windows Server/client have daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly retention policies.
trans-unit.target: No, both DPM and Windows Server/client have daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly retention policies.

trans-unit.source: Can I configure my retention policies selectively – i.e. configure weekly and daily but not yearly and monthly?
trans-unit.target: Can I configure my retention policies selectively – i.e. configure weekly and daily but not yearly and monthly?

trans-unit.source: Yes, the Azure Backup retention structure allows you to have full flexibility in defining the retention policy as per your requirements.
trans-unit.target: Yes, the Azure Backup retention structure allows you to have full flexibility in defining the retention policy as per your requirements.

trans-unit.source: Can I “schedule a backup” at 6pm and specify “retention policies” at a different time?
trans-unit.target: Can I “schedule a backup” at 6pm and specify “retention policies” at a different time?

trans-unit.source: Retention policies can only be applied on backup points.
trans-unit.target: Retention policies can only be applied on backup points.

trans-unit.source: In the following image, the retention policy is specified for backups taken at 12am and 6pm.
trans-unit.target: In the following image, the retention policy is specified for backups taken at 12am and 6pm.

trans-unit.source: Is an incremental copy transferred for the retention policies scheduled?
trans-unit.target: Is an incremental copy transferred for the retention policies scheduled?

trans-unit.source: No, the incremental copy is sent based on the time mentioned in the backup schedule page.
trans-unit.target: No, the incremental copy is sent based on the time mentioned in the backup schedule page.

trans-unit.source: The points that can be retained are determined based on the retention policy.
trans-unit.target: The points that can be retained are determined based on the retention policy.

trans-unit.source: If a backup is retained for a long duration, does it take more time to recover an older data point?
trans-unit.target: If a backup is retained for a long duration, does it take more time to recover an older data point?

trans-unit.source: No – the time to recover the oldest or the newest point is the same.
trans-unit.target: No – the time to recover the oldest or the newest point is the same.

trans-unit.source: Each recovery point behaves like a full point.
trans-unit.target: Each recovery point behaves like a full point.

trans-unit.source: If each recovery point is like a full point, does it impact the total billable backup storage?
trans-unit.target: If each recovery point is like a full point, does it impact the total billable backup storage?

trans-unit.source: Typical long-term retention point products store backup data as full points.
trans-unit.target: Typical long-term retention point products store backup data as full points.

trans-unit.source: The full points are storage *inefficient* but are easier and faster to restore.
trans-unit.target: The full points are storage *inefficient* but are easier and faster to restore.

trans-unit.source: Incremental copies are storage *efficient* but require you to restore a chain of data, which impacts your recovery time.
trans-unit.target: Incremental copies are storage *efficient* but require you to restore a chain of data, which impacts your recovery time.

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup storage architecture gives you the best of both worlds by optimally storing data for fast restores and incurring low storage costs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup storage architecture gives you the best of both worlds by optimally storing data for fast restores and incurring low storage costs.

trans-unit.source: This data storage approach ensures that your ingress and egress bandwidth is used efficiently.
trans-unit.target: This data storage approach ensures that your ingress and egress bandwidth is used efficiently.

trans-unit.source: Both the amount of data storage and the time needed to recover the data, is kept to a minimum.
trans-unit.target: Both the amount of data storage and the time needed to recover the data, is kept to a minimum.

trans-unit.source: Is there a limit on the number of recovery points that can be created?
trans-unit.target: Is there a limit on the number of recovery points that can be created?

trans-unit.source: We have eliminated limits on recovery points.
trans-unit.target: We have eliminated limits on recovery points.

trans-unit.source: You can create as many recovery points as you desire.
trans-unit.target: You can create as many recovery points as you desire.

trans-unit.source: Why is the amount of data transferred in backup not equal to the amount of data I backed up?
trans-unit.target: Why is the amount of data transferred in backup not equal to the amount of data I backed up?

trans-unit.source: All the data that is backed up is compressed and encrypted before being transferred.
trans-unit.target: All the data that is backed up is compressed and encrypted before being transferred.

trans-unit.source: Once the compression and encryption is applied, the data in the backup vault is 30-40% smaller.
trans-unit.target: Once the compression and encryption is applied, the data in the backup vault is 30-40% smaller.

trans-unit.source: Is there a way to adjust the amount of bandwidth used by the Backup service?
trans-unit.target: Is there a way to adjust the amount of bandwidth used by the Backup service?

trans-unit.source: Yes, use the **Change Properties** option in the Backup Agent to adjust bandwidth.
trans-unit.target: Yes, use the **Change Properties** option in the Backup Agent to adjust bandwidth.

trans-unit.source: Adjust the amount of bandwidth and the times when you use that bandwidth.
trans-unit.target: Adjust the amount of bandwidth and the times when you use that bandwidth.

trans-unit.source: My internet bandwidth is limited for the amount of data I need to back up.
trans-unit.target: My internet bandwidth is limited for the amount of data I need to back up.

trans-unit.source: Is there a way I can move data to a certain location with a large network pipe and push that data into Azure?
trans-unit.target: Is there a way I can move data to a certain location with a large network pipe and push that data into Azure?

trans-unit.source: You can back up data into Azure via the standard online backup process, or you can use the Azure Import/Export service to transfer data to blob storage in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can back up data into Azure via the standard online backup process, or you can use the Azure Import/Export service to transfer data to blob storage in Azure.

trans-unit.source: There are no additional ways of getting backup date into Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: There are no additional ways of getting backup date into Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: For information on how to use the Azure Import/Export service with Azure Backup, please see the [Offline Backup workflow](backup-azure-backup-import-export) article.
trans-unit.target: For information on how to use the Azure Import/Export service with Azure Backup, please see the [Offline Backup workflow](backup-azure-backup-import-export) article.

trans-unit.source: How many recoveries can I perform on the data that is backed up to Azure?
trans-unit.target: How many recoveries can I perform on the data that is backed up to Azure?

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of recoveries from Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of recoveries from Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: Do I have to pay for the egress traffic from Azure data center during recoveries?
trans-unit.target: Do I have to pay for the egress traffic from Azure data center during recoveries?

trans-unit.source: Your recoveries are free and you are not charged for the egress traffic.
trans-unit.target: Your recoveries are free and you are not charged for the egress traffic.

trans-unit.source: Is the data sent to Azure encrypted?
trans-unit.target: Is the data sent to Azure encrypted?

trans-unit.source: Data is encrypted on the on-premises server/client/SCDPM machine using AES256 and the data is sent over a secure HTTPS link.
trans-unit.target: Data is encrypted on the on-premises server/client/SCDPM machine using AES256 and the data is sent over a secure HTTPS link.

trans-unit.source: Is the backup data on Azure encrypted as well?
trans-unit.target: Is the backup data on Azure encrypted as well?

trans-unit.source: The data sent to Azure remains encrypted (at rest).
trans-unit.target: The data sent to Azure remains encrypted (at rest).

trans-unit.source: Microsoft does not decrypt the backup data at any point.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft does not decrypt the backup data at any point.

trans-unit.source: What is the minimum length of encryption key used to encrypt backup data?
trans-unit.target: What is the minimum length of encryption key used to encrypt backup data?

trans-unit.source: The encryption key should be at least 16 characters.
trans-unit.target: The encryption key should be at least 16 characters.

trans-unit.source: What happens if I misplace the encryption key?
trans-unit.target: What happens if I misplace the encryption key?

trans-unit.source: Can I recover the data (or) can Microsoft recover the data?
trans-unit.target: Can I recover the data (or) can Microsoft recover the data?

trans-unit.source: The key used to encrypt the backup data is present only on the customer premises.
trans-unit.target: The key used to encrypt the backup data is present only on the customer premises.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft does not maintain a copy in Azure and does not have any access to the key.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft does not maintain a copy in Azure and does not have any access to the key.

trans-unit.source: If the customer misplaces the key, Microsoft cannot recover the backup data.
trans-unit.target: If the customer misplaces the key, Microsoft cannot recover the backup data.

trans-unit.source: How do I change the cache location specified for the Azure Backup agent?
trans-unit.target: How do I change the cache location specified for the Azure Backup agent?

trans-unit.source: Go sequentially through the bullet list below to change the cache location.
trans-unit.target: Go sequentially through the bullet list below to change the cache location.

trans-unit.source: Stop the Backup engine by executing the following command in an elevated command prompt:
trans-unit.target: Stop the Backup engine by executing the following command in an elevated command prompt:

trans-unit.source: Instead, copy the cache space folder to a different drive with sufficient space.
trans-unit.target: Instead, copy the cache space folder to a different drive with sufficient space.

trans-unit.source: The original cache space can be removed after confirming the backups are working with the new cache space.
trans-unit.target: The original cache space can be removed after confirming the backups are working with the new cache space.

trans-unit.source: Update the following registry entries with the path to the new cache space folder.
trans-unit.target: Update the following registry entries with the path to the new cache space folder.

trans-unit.source: Re-start the Backup engine by executing the following command in an elevated command prompt:
trans-unit.target: Re-start the Backup engine by executing the following command in an elevated command prompt:

trans-unit.source: Once the backup creation is successfully completed in the new cache location, you can remove the original cache folder.
trans-unit.target: Once the backup creation is successfully completed in the new cache location, you can remove the original cache folder.
